description:
Shoot People in Space is a set of rules for science fiction skirmish battles. It is aimed at being dramatic, exciting and occasionally over the top game of battle and space adventure. It is not meant to be a hardcore military game and the results are not meant to be particularly realistic.

-description from rulebook

Battles are fought in phases with alternating activations: In the action phase your figures take turns carrying out one action (moving, firing, doing something else) while in the firefight phase most figures can fire (potentially shooting a second time).

Combat uses a simple 2D6 table with several unexpected factors built in: Firers can fumble or inflict critical hits and the use of a separate Threat die can cause surprise reactions such as the targets diving for cover or firing back. Gun battles plays out quickly and chaotically.

Intended for head-to-head play with 10 scenario objectives to pick from, but offers tools for non player forces and a random unit generator. These are great for solo play or to have a third party force show up mid battle if you like.

With about 8-15 figures per side, SPiS occupies a middle ground between the man-to-man combat of Five Parsecs From Home and the larger battles of Renegade Scout / Clash on the Fringe by the same publisher.

Through their love of tabletop games and boba tea, the founders of Landes Toys and Games LLC bring you BOBA GOBA!

The Goal of the game is simple, earn as much points as you can by collecting Boba cards but be careful because behind every turn of a card may be a hazard.

Game play is as simple as it gets, all the cards are distributed amongst the players and placed face down. Players then take turns flipping over cards that will either earn them points, affect other players or set aside to help themselves.

THEY LOOK LIKE US. THEY SOUND LIKE US. BUT THEY ARE NOT HUMAN!

They Live: The Card Game – Save The City/Enslave The City is an asymmetrical multiplayer card focused on strategy, teamwork, and deceit. Working collectively is the only way to survive, but not everyone is playing for the same team.

Hidden among the group are secret Invaders determined to capture the city. The humans outnumber them, but the Invaders have the advantage of knowing what the teams are. You will start losing health shortly after the game begins, there is no avoiding it. you must act fast! Each turn begins with new resources being drawn to the middle of the table. These include weapons, ammunition, city parts and more. Players take turns to take and equip any cards they need.

As Invaders, your goal is to enslave the city. You must stay hidden, act human, and try to collect the city cards to capture different areas of the city. The more you hold, the closer you are to winning.

As Humans, your goal is to work out who among the team is an Invader. You need to take them down before it’s too late!

-description from developer

Invisible - Unsichtbar - is a solitaire wargame that depicts the struggles of a U-Boot Kommandant and his crew during WWII.

The game takes place through a series of turns where you will be patrolling for merchant ships and destroying as many of them as possible.

SETUP

Choose between the two types of U-Boots available: Type VIIC or IXC. Pick the ID, U-boot nickname and Kommandant name.

Place the U-BOOT markers at the first black dot to the right of the Approach box and the other one on top of the U-BOOT Depth box. Place the Escort marker on top of the Escort box.

Now you are ready to start your patrol.

THE GAME

Step 1: The Approach: Roll 2d6 to find out the events for the day. Check under the Approach box and resolve event.

Step 2: If you roll a SIGHTING, roll 3d6 and total it. Place the 3 dice (they represent 3 ships of a Convoy you Sighted) at that range total. Example: The roll is an 8, place dice on the Medium Rage (7-12)

Step 3: Roll 1d6 for the Weather/Time of Day.

Now you may decide if you want to engage the Convoy. Night and bad weather can really hurt your chances of accomplishing your mission before the Convoy gets away or you get chased off by an Escort...choose your engagements wisely. You are never obligated to engage with a Convoy but don't forget...your main goal is to sink as many merchant ships as possible and make your way back home.

If you do engage with the Convoy, follow the Sequence of Play thereafter until the Convoy gets away or you decide to let them go yourself, or you get sunk by an Escort : )

A Successful patrol is achieved when you make your way back home with 30+ tons of sunken ships.

I hope this is helpful to get the game to the table faster and expedite the beginning of your career as a U-BOOT Kommandant.

One more thing...enjoy the game!

BattleReady Wargames signing off.

ps: please leave a review on the bgg website (link below) so the game can get ranked. ? Thank you

https://boardgamegeek.com/boardgame/381111/invisible-unsichtbar

Example of play #1

Let's say I have a Sighting. Weather is Day/Good and rolled an 8 for Convoy placement (medium range - bottom dot. ), U-Boot at the Approach. I decide to engage with them.

Round 1

1- I decide to stay surfaced and move up 2 black dots which places me at the top dot in the close range.

2- ASW phase - nothing happens.

3 - Convoy moves up to the top dot in the Medium range.

4 - I decide to use 4 torpedoes. I have a +1 range DRM (I'm at the close range and Convoy is at the Medium range - only 1 range away)

My to hit number now is 4 + 1 DRM for a total of 5 or above. I shoot all 4 for 5,4,2,6. 2 hits, not bad at all. Now I must roll to see if they actually explode on impact. 1s are duds and everything else is an explosion. I roll 2,2 - phew that was close.

Now I roll for tonnage on the bottom of the page. 8 tons total, pretty good score so far.

5 - Damage control - nothing happens. No injuries and no damage to the boat yet.

Round 2

- I stay surfaced and move up 2 dots to the top dot of the Medium range. During Day/good per rules I'm automatically found.

-ASW - Escort moves down the escort track now. He is coming for me.

- Convoy moves up to the Long range dot.

- Since I'm reloading all of my torpedoes this turn I can't fire them yet. I decide to use my deck gun against the lonely ship.

I roll 2d6 to a base hit of 4 + 1 DRM range. (U-boot at Medium range and Convoy at the Long range) for a total of 5 or above to hit. I roll 3 and 4. Not great.

- Damage control phase - nothing happens.

to be continued.

Doggerland was a landmass that connected Great Britain to mainland Europe that disappeared under the North Sea after the last ice age. Humans lived on these fertile lands where multiple resources and animals were found.

In Doggerland, you play a clan at around 15,000 BCE. Your goal is to expand your clan in order to leave a trace of its existence for centuries to come. Players increase their population, make crafts, paint murals in caves, raise megaliths for the gods, and (most of all) survive the rigors of the seasons. To do this, they explore the surrounding territory and adapt to the resources at their disposal. The territory differs in each game, thanks to modular tiles.

Each round, players program their actions, then carry them out. These actions vary, based on available resources, abundance or scarcity around their villages, and also based on the actions of other players. As time passes, resources run out, and clans must migrate to find what they need for their development and survival.

In each clan, there is a leader who brings bonuses, and a shaman who allows powerful and unique actions thanks to knowledge and magic. After 6-8 seasons, the clan with the most points wins.

Cozy Oaks is a quiet yet humble little village off the Coast. Though the land that surrounds Cozy Oaks is breath-taking, the village itself needs a bit of work. Mayor Williams had an idea that could bring business back into this little town -- Restore the farmlands! Help wanted signs were posted on every corner and as luck would have it, you have taken interest. However, it appears that you have competition.

The Mayor is willing to give each of you 3 years, during which, you will need to grow crops, care for animals, mine for ores, craft new equipment, and do the occasional fishing. If you have the most Star Points at the end of the 3 years, you will be deemed the official Farmer of Cozy Oaks!

Cozy Oaks is unique in that it uses a hand of cards, called Skills, in a very clever way. Each farmer has 10 Skills in their hand, and most Skills will cost time. The player must discard Skills from their hand in order to satisfy this cost, giving the player less decisions for future turns. As the seasons and years pass, players will be upgrading their Skills. And just like life, the more interest you have in a Skill, the more time it takes up in your day. Players will need to upgrade wisely. The only way to retrieve the played and discarded Skills is for the player to Sleep. This allows the player to regain all of their cards back. Each decision is crucial, from playing certain Skills and when to spend time on other things.

GAME SUMMARY

Cozy Oaks is played over 3 Years with each year split into 4 Seasons: Spring, Summer, Fall, and Winter for a total of 12 rounds. Each player moves at their own pace. This means that one player may be on Year 2 Spring while the other player is still on Year 1 Fall. The goal in Cozy Oaks is to have the most Star Points at the end of the game. To achieve this, players must play Skill cards to work on their farms or visit locations in town. Players will need to manage their resources and time wisely.

Each player will begin the game with all ten Level 1 Skill cards in their hand. They will set their Level 2 and Level 3 decks aside for now. Each of the Level 2 and 3 decks can be looked through at any time.

PLAYER'S TURN

1) The player MUST choose a Skill card from their hand to play.

2) Be sure to pay for the Time Cost, if any.

3) The chosen Skill card is placed face up on the table in front of the player.

3a) Cards that were discarded for paying the Time Cost are placed face down and sideways next to the played Skill card.

3b) Be sure to keep the “Played Skill” pile separate from the 
“Discarded Time” pile.

3c) Cards that have been played or discarded remain on the table until the player plays their Sleep Skill in which all cards will be returned to their hand.

4) The player then performs the Skill card’s effect.

5) After the player has completed their Skill, it is then the other player’s turn.

-description from designer

A solo, "DIE" rolling game of mitigating consequences where you play as Bobby Butcher, a three-armed anti-hero trying to speed away in his groovy van as re-animated roadkill attempt to chase him down.

Road Kill(ed) is played on 2 poker-sized cards with 7 dice and 2 penny-sized coins. You roll 3 Action Dice, then decide IF you'll spend your Skill Points to mitigate the dice or not. Choose wisely, because the dice values you end the round with could have dire consequences... 
 You win by reaching the end of the Distance Track and lose if your Fuel reduces to 1, either Tire falls beyond the third notch, or if the enemy die reaches the end of the Distance Track before you.

Road Kill(ed) is part of A. R. Curry's DEADVERSE, which is a series of dark-humored standalone solo games that will, over time, tell an overarching story. Each game in the series will come with bonus content compatible with DEAD END, the core game in the series.

—description from the publisher

A band of robbers has just emptied the vaults of a bank, and now they are attempting a truly audacious escape.

Use all your instincts and wits, close off the city and try to catch them before they disappear.

Challenge Level 4/5

Contents:
1 Story Booklet
1 Map
Game Guide
64 Cards

Game for young Children where vehicles are hidden behind houses, are assigned to different places and compared to each other. There are three recommended modes to play for children in different ages. 

     discover and describe
     assigning 
     hide and seek


Goal of the latter ones is to find all hidden vehicles behind the houses and assign them to the right location.

Ever wondered what you'd look like as a Disney villain, or as Olaf? Find out in Drawsome Disney, a hilarious drawing party game from Ridley's Games!

Roll the dice at the beginning of each normal round to determine who everyone draws from their card, like a Mash Up combination of two characters or the movie companion of any character on their card. In the bonus round, cards will have challenges like drawing someone at the table as a specific character. The person with the most points at the end of five rounds wins.

Kaël is a game of speed and strategy. The main goal will be to get rid of as many cards as possible to get the lowest score in your hands. However, pay attention to the cards of other players when you pronounce Kaël. Certain combinations of cards can be equal to 0 even though a player has 4 cards (example: -1/1/0/0 = 0).

This game is based on a point system. The goal is to be the last player to reach a score higher than 100. To do this, you must obtain the lowest possible score at the end of each round, the score is calculated by adding up the value of the cards in your hands at the end of each round.

At the end of the different rounds, the respective scores of each player will be added up. The first player to exceed 100 points will be eliminated and the game will continue until there is only one player below the 100 point threshold.

Kaël est un jeu de rapidité et de stratégie. Le but principal sera de vous délester d’un maximum de cartes afin d’obtenir le plus petit score entre vos mains. Faites néanmoins attention aux cartes des autres joueurs lorsque vous prononcez Kaël. Certaines combinaisons de cartes peuvent être égales à 0 alors même qu’un joueur dispose de 4 cartes (exemple: -1/1/0/0 = 0).

Le jeu est basé sur un système de points. Le but est d’être le dernier joueur à atteindre  un score supérieur à 100. Pour ce faire, il conviendra d’obtenir le score le plus bas possible à chaque fin de manche, le score se calculant en additionnant la valeur des cartes entre vos mains, à chaque fin de manche.

A l’issue des différentes manches, les scores respectifs de chaque joueur vont se cumuler. Le premier joueur à dépasser 100 points sera éliminé et la partie se poursuivra jusqu’à ce qu’il n’y ait plus qu’un joueur en dessous du seuil des 100 points.

Cloud Nine: A Game of Wonderful Things celebrates the things in life that bring us joy, with illustrations by Lisa Congdon.

Do you love campfires or video games? Wandering around a new city or falling in love? How about the feeling of losing track of time, being out in nature, or listening to music that moves you? We all have special things that make us feel alive and connected to the world, and playing Cloud Nine was made to share them with each other.

In Cloud Nine, players choose from over 300 Cloud Cards to build their personalized collection of nine treasured things, with 50 Action Cards to mix up gameplay.
The Cloud Cards represent a wide assortment of things and experiences, big and small, that bring out a range of emotions from joy and happiness to wonder and amazement, as well as simple pleasures like favorite foods.
Each Cloud Card also includes questions that players can use as conversation prompts to learn more about why we love the things we do.

How to play: To start the game, draw nine random Cloud Cards from the deck and place them face up in a 3x3 grid, known as “the Sky.” The Sky is shared by all players, and must always be filled as cards are taken.
On each turn, players can choose from one of two options:
Take a Cloud Card from the Sky. If you see something you love in the Sky, take the Cloud Card and add it to your own collection. Replace the card you took with a new card from the deck.
Remove a row of Cloud Cards from the Sky. If you don’t love any of the Cloud Cards, you can discard an entire row in any direction, replacing it with three new cards from the deck to choose from. If you still don’t love any of the cards, your turn ends without adding a new card to your collection.
If any card you’ve drawn from the deck is an Action Card, you must use it immediately, following its instructions before ending your turn.
The first player to collect nine Cloud Cards is the winner! Now try spinning all nine cards into a story about how you’d love to spend one beautiful day packed full with things you love. (Bonus: Go out and do it!)

—description from the publisher

"Stay on board!"

A dexterity game where players take turns loading plastic "stuff" onto a swaying cargo ship. Each player has seven containers and two barrels, one normal and one "explosive/radioactive" (twice as heavy), and a spinner determines what needs to be loaded on each player's turn. Containers must be loaded by a loading fork and must always touch previously placed containers from the same player, while barrels can be more freely placed by hand to either balance the ship or to make it trickier for the next player to load their cargo. Matters are further complicated by a pesky pelican who thinks that "Le Barjo" is simply the best perching point in the whole harbour, and always insist on sitting at the highest point of the boat.

Tipping cargo overboard is bad as you get all of your own tipped cargo back, while any other players' pieces are out of the game, making it easier for them; the first one to get rid of all their cargo wins.

Similar to:


     Riff Raff

You are a planet.  You became self-aware about twenty minutes ago.  Five minutes ago, you discovered that you have the power to manipulate the environments of your surface.  Three minutes ago, you managed to create life out of the very elements.  Needless to say, these developments shocked and impressed the sentient life forms that had been forming tribes all over you for hundreds of generations.

Then, one minute ago, you felt the distinct sensation that you’ve awakened before.  What were you doing?  It seemed very important at the time.

Two Thousand Years is a Make-As-You-Play campaign of solitaire card games.  Each game represents 100 years of warfare between your tribes.  Each tribe is represented by a card.  You make the cards yourself, and they are modified during and after every game with advancements, corruption, extra staying power, and many other characteristics.

At the end your campaign, whether you win or lose, you will have generated a history of your peoples (of any type that you imagine) and important landmarks (also pretty much up to you).

It is a game of patience and foresight and planning.  The board will want to clear itself, and you need to stop it by using clever sequences and mystic powers!  Rash decisions may carry brutal, permanent consequences.  You might want to have a space in your home where you can leave a game undisturbed.

—description from the publisher

Kauri is a strategic, asymmetric board game with high replayability that brings the historical settlement of New Zealand to life on a beautifully crafted game board with detailed wooden pieces. In this board game, four unique factions with distinct abilities, their own decks of cards, objectives, and gameplay mechanics battle for dominance: the MÄori, the Englishman, the Possums, and the Kiwis.

At the heart of the conflict stands the Kauri tree, the island’s iconic symbol — but each faction follows a different strategy and scores points in its own way. The Kiwis must fight for their survival, while the Possums seek to expand their territory. The Englishman will first deforest the land before hunting the Possums, while the MÄori build their sacred temples (Whare Nui).

Over five intense rounds, players must strategically play their cards to take control of the island while preventing their opponents from gaining too many points. A game filled with strategy, historical authenticity, and dynamic challenges—will you claim victory?

The Cypher Files is an utterly unique reading experience. In this brain-bending interactive game, you'll solve puzzles on every page, and obtain keys to move forward by submitting answers online. To solve each puzzle, you'll need to think outside the book. You are an agent of CY.P.H.E.R., the secret international agency working on 'unsolvable' code-based cases. Called upon to investigate cryptic clues discovered in the wake of a series of mysterious disappearances, the clock is ticking to crack the codes before it's too late. To escape this book, you must write, draw, search, fold and cut pages, explore virtual escape rooms, and think laterally to identify the perpetrator and solve the mystery. All you need to play is a pencil, a pair of scissors, an internet connection, and a curious mind.

Steig ein! is a simple game of dice in which 2 to 4 players try to get their playing pieces from their home bases into buses.

The board depicts a circle of 48 playing fields encircling a wheel with 4 buses. The buses each offer 4 seats, a door field and a door step. In each corner of the board is a home base where the four pieces of each player start.

The players take their turn by rolling the dice and moving any one of their pieces either over the 48 playing fields or into a bus. On the surrounding playing fields, there is no limit to the number of pieces on a field. Inside the buses, only one piece per field is allowed. On the door field and the door step, players can be captured and returned to their base.

If a player rolls a 6, they may not move a piece but has to roll again. The wheel is then turned clockwise the respective number of fields of the second roll. If the roll is a 6 again the wheel is turned 6 fields and the dice is rolled again and the wheel turned again.

The first player to move all four pieces into a seat of any bus wins the game.

—user summary

“TWILIGHT DANCE is a Cold War themed ‘worker placement’ chaining game, in which two adversaries take turns to place and move hidden identity playing pieces on a four by four grid featuring sixteen European capitals. The city of Cold War Berlin is represented by an additional special space in the centre of the board.”

What the two adversaries need to play:

     The Print & Play game board (available in the files section)
     16 wooden playing pieces (tokens, pawns or blocks etc) [8 each of two different colours]
     The 16 Print & Play images that need to be affixed to the underside of the playing pieces [4 Agents, 2 Moles and 2 Decoys each]


Objective of the game and how to play:
The winner of the game is the Spymaster with the most points at the end of the game.  The game ends after all 16 pieces (representing KGB and SIS Agents (or Operations if you prefer) have been played out – i.e., both players’ hands of playing pieces are empty; or, after the conclusion of an agreed number of turns (usually set at 12).

Pieces are played to the board, which is a 4-by-4 grid forming a schematic representation of key European Cold War capitals, with the city of Berlin represented by an additional ‘special’ space in the middle of the board.  The cities represented - in addition to Berlin - are Oslo, Copenhagen, Stockholm, Helsinki, London, Amsterdam, Warsaw, Moscow, Paris Bonn, Prague, Vienna, Lisbon, Madrid, Rome and Sofia.
Points are awarded at the end of a game for each chain of two or three adjacent cities the two players have Agents or Moles in.  Chains can be orthogonal or diagonal.  Chains of two earn 2 points and chains of three 3 points.  Berlin cannot be used to accumulate points but has a special role in the game in that it is the only location on the board in which ‘stacking’ is allowed.  At player discretion however ‘supremacy’ in Berlin may be used to adjudicate ties.

Players can do one of the following five things on their turn:
1 Place one of their pieces in any one of the sixteen cities, provided the space representing that city is empty.
2 Relocate one of their own pieces already on the board to any other city, provided the space representing the new location is empty.
3 Place a piece as 1 above and then “shunt” it and all other pieces one location in any single orthogonal plane. *
4 Place a piece in Berlin or “stack” a piece on an opponent’s piece already there. (Maximum stack: one piece each.) 
5 Use the topmost piece in Berlin, if it is theirs, to shunt a piece or pieces along any one of the four diagonal planes extending from the city. *

[*Note: If a piece is shunted off the board, it enters the other player’s hand, irrespective of allegiance.]

Scoring examples are illustrated in the rules located in the files section.

Notes on restrictions and other essential rules:
In the basic game, players cannot “relocate” their adversary’s pieces.  They can only be moved by ‘shunting’.

Players cannot forego their turn if they possess unplaced pieces.

‘Shunting’ is orthogonal from the 16 cities comprising the 4-by-4 board.  It is diagonal from Berlin.

A piece passed to a player as a result of shunting should not be examined by the shunting player.  The player receiving the piece will be able to look at its hidden side once it is in their hand.

Pawns and stacking
Players preferring to use pawns for playing pieces can simulate stacking by the way the pawns are positioned in the Berlin space on the board – a Top and Bottom within the space is clearly apparent.
     
Variant rules
A number of variant rules can be adopted at set-up by mutual agreement of the players.  These are included with the base game.

—description from the designer

During the game, the player builds a deck of cards that represents a scientific base operating in alien territory.

The game switches between Relief Steps, where you choose new cards to add into your deck, and Combat Steps, where alien waves of increasing difficulty are fought. Both enemy waves and cards eligible to be recruited are randomized (drawn from a previously shuffled deck).

During Combat Steps, your military cards can be played to destroy aliens or to repair your defenses. Then, surviving aliens damage your base back, deactivating your Shields and eventually lowering its Constitution rating.

Your scientific cards grant victory points and useful abilities, but eventually clog up your deck leaving your base vulnerable. Pursuing sinergetic card combinations and keeping the right balance between scientific and military assets is essential.

Aliens cannot be defeated. Game continues until your base is destroyed (by reaching 0 Constitution) and the game is lost, or the player decides to evacuate, cashing out the acquired victory points into a final score rating.

From the moment the evacuation is requested until it actually happens, two more waves of aliens must be fought, so pushing your luck too far might end in failure.

-description by the designer

Aliens have no technological nor numerical advantage. Humanity is unable to stop their slow advance due to the strange dimensional energy that surrounds them, against which our weapons and defenses are unprepared. This Anomaly is an unknown force, that only our dreams and subconscious may perceive.

We're vulnerable to its terror and delirium, but our scientists claim that this weakness comes with the potential for mastering it. Many survivors of the invasion have been elevated to a higher psionic state.

Now we're focused on Astalos, a terraformed quadrant under enemy control, still wrapped in traces of Anomaly. Our plan is to deploy there different operational bases so that our scientific personnel can carry out tests and measurements.

Our presence will attract hostile response. General, your mission is to defend one of those bases to the best of your ability, so you can then withdraw with the maximum amount of data and samples. You'll be deployed and evacuated by a Class IV Frigate, that will be kept hidden in supraorbital location and therefore will only be able to provide limited support.

You'll get the details during the transfer. Dismissed.

-from the rulebook

Do you love animals? Have you imagined what it would be like to work in an animal reserve? Help us count everyone and pay close attention so as not to neglect anyone. Save these endangered species with your math skills and have fun with these adorable animals.

In Animal Keeper, you will be in the care of various endangered species such as koalas, pandas, tigers, elephants and monkeys. You will have to count the animals as fast as you can, but always following a specific way to count them.

—description from the publisher (translated)

¿Te encantan los animales? ¿Has imaginado cómo sería trabajar en una reserva animal? Ayúdanos a contar a todos y presta mucha atención para no descuidar a ninguno. Salva a estas especies en peligro de extinción con tus habilidades matemáticas y diviértete con estos animales tan adorables.

En Animal Keeper, estarás al cuidado de diversas especies en peligro de extinción como koalas, pandas, tigres, elefantes y monos. Tendrás que contar los animales lo más rápido que puedas, pero siempre siguiendo una forma específica para contarlos.

—description from the publisher

The Battle of Mackinac Island is a solitaire and two-player game designed to be played in 30 minutes or less. The player takes on the role of the American commander during the Battle of Mackinac Island, fought in the summer of 1814, the final year of the War of 1812.

—description from the publisher

Enter a magical world of mythical beasts and ancient dragons in Dragon Eclipse! Uncover the secrets of the eclipse that changed everything and discover the dangerous and treacherous world that awaits you. Explore a vivid and immersive world filled with majestic and unique creatures you can battle, tame, catch, and train. Each creature has a unique deck of cards you can use in combat and special abilities, offering endless tactical possibilities to master.

In Dragon Eclipse! discover and befriend Mystling, elemental creatures roaming the land. Complete their personal quests, grow and train them, discover cards, and build powerful decks for your favorite Mystlings. Execute your combo in a highly tactical combat arena. Discover the great mystery of the Eclipse in an epic 12-scenario campaign, where you will make a lot of new friends and some enemies. You can also compete with a friend in the 1vs1 arena challenge OR play a fully gameplay-focused roguelite mode.

—description from the publisher

Snow White, The Little Mermaid, Cinderella, and many other fairy tale princesses are celebrating a five-day party. The prince charmings, who have not been invited, will try to infiltrate the ball to propose marriage to the girls. As a princess, you have to avoid marriage proposals and remain single and independent after the celebrations.

Rebel Princess takes place over five rounds, representing the five days of a party, and each round has a special rule that makes each game totally different. The general mechanisms are those of trick-taking games, in which each player plays a numbered card into each trick, following one of the four suits in the game. The player with the highest number of the suit that started the trick takes all the cards of that trick — but that's not necessarily good as players want to avoid taking cards with prince charmings, who each bring one marriage proposal, aside from the enchanted frog who brings five proposals. The player with the fewest marriage proposals after five rounds wins.

Importantly, each player assumes the role of a different fairy tale princess and has a special ability that they can use once per round.

—description from the publisher

Many years after the confrontation with Van Helsing, Dracula landed in Whitby, England once again. The citizens of Whitby sought help from the vampire hunter, Professor Van Helsing. Will Van Helsing defeat Dracula before he transforms all the inhabitants into vampires?

In Dracula vs Van Helsing, each player controls one of the title characters. Van Helsing must remove all of Dracula's life points to win, but if Dracula turns all four inhabitants of the same district into vampires first, Dracula wins.

The game lasts at most five rounds. Each round, players play in turn (starting with Dracula), drawing a card, then discarding that card or swapping it with one of the five cards on their rack to trigger the discarded card's ability. Cards come in eight types, each with its own effect. Instead of drawing (and discarding) a card, a player can call for the end of the round. In order to choose this action, at least six cards need to be in the discard pile. After the opponent plays one last turn, the round ends; otherwise, the round ends when the deck is empty.

At the end of a round, players compare the five cards on their rack. Each card corresponds to one of the five districts on the game board. If Dracula has the higher-valued card, one of the humans in this district is converted into a vampire; if Van Helsing is higher, Dracula loses a health point. If one of the game-winning conditions is met, the game ends immediately.

—description from the publisher

Your goal in Less Chess is to place the opponent's king into check in three different ways at the same time.

To set up, lay out the 3x6 game board, then place each player's king on the designated space on the game board. Shuffle each player's deck of cards, then choose a start player.

On a turn, reveal the top card of your deck, then either take the depicted piece from your reserve and place it orthogonally adjacent to one of your pieces currently in play or move a piece on the game board of the depicted type following the normal movement rules of chess. You can capture any opponent's piece other than the king. If you move a pawn to the opponent's back line (or place a pawn there), you promote it to a piece not currently in play.

If you ever have the opponent's king in check by three pieces at the same time, you win.

Each turn in Dixit, one player is the storyteller, chooses one of the six cards in their hand, then makes up a sentence based on that card's image and says it out loud without showing the card to the other players. Each other player then selects the card in their hand that best matches the sentence and gives the selected card to the storyteller, without showing it to anyone else.

The storyteller shuffles their card with all of the received cards, then reveals all of these cards. Each player other than the storyteller then secretly guesses which card belongs to the storyteller. If nobody or everybody guesses the correct card, the storyteller scores 0 points, and each other player scores 2 points. Otherwise, the storyteller and whoever found the correct answer score 3 points. Additionally, the non-storyteller players score 1 point for every vote received by their card.

The game ends when the deck is empty or if a player has scored at least 30 points. In either case, the player with the most points wins.

Dixit: Disney Edition features 84 cards, with each card representing one of 84 films in the Disney or Pixar catalog from Steamboat Willie to Turning Red.

Dice the Boss utilizes custom dice to bring together a co-operative group of 2-5 adventurers to take on the roles of heros, gain skills, then throw dice at a series of bosses until the party wins or loses.  With exponential combinations of parties and a solid epic 2 player mode this game is highly replayable and utilizes the fun and family friendly dice, art, and themes that Arcanist's Armory has developed.

Every hero has health, speed, defense, and attack stats as well as a few skills that will grow and develop as you defeat the zany bosses such as Quasi-Moto the hunchback biker or the sinister Dead of Knight.  This game is meant to fill the gap between serious campaign crawlers and simple dice games so that everyone of any skill level or strategy apetite can come together to play and enjoy.

—description from the publisher

The second 6-card expansion for Galdor's Grip.

Using the clever deck construction feature in Galdor's Grip, players can (randomly) mix and match any number of non-essential cards from the Core Set with cards from an expansion to create new card and deck and interactions! This expansion offers new scoring objectives and ways to manipulate the order of the deck.

Galdor's Grip is a solo fantasy card game played completely in your hands. As you move through the deck, you’ll need to carefully manipulate the order and orientation of the cards to gain more knowledge of your surroundings and avoid hazards until Galdor is in position to neutralize Feragot. The base game is needed to play this expansion.

In this game, you will be able to try to blunt the Japanese thrust into China and SE Asia. The campaigns will cover the fighting in Burma (particularly Rangoon), China and Indochina. There will be new pilots and targets, as well as new events and campaigns. The core game is based on the whole of the AVG with each squadron's pilots being identified by the squadron emblem.

There are also new rules governing starting skill levels and abilities of some pilots created. There are also rules for replacing the pilots or rotating the squadron out based on casualties. The event cards are based on actual events that the Tigers experienced in their short sojourn in defending SE Asia.

—description from the publisher

When the celebrations and dancing have ended for the night, the citizens of Rio de Janeiro wander home, but in the darkness and afterglow, danger lurks: Coteries of vampires seek their prey, while Hunter cells research and investigate the unknown.

Rivals is an expandable card game for 2-4 players based on the popular roleplaying game set in the World of Darkness. Each player controls a group of vampires or Hunters who seek to dominate their Rivals by attacking their foes, starting Conspiracies, advancing Agendas, and hunting mortals and monsters. Both Hunters and vampires can appear in the same game, so be ready for anything!
  
Vampire: The Masquerade – The Hunters & The Hunted is a new core set that contains everything you need to play right out of the box, including four pre-constructed player decks: 2 Hunter Cells (Faithful & Inquisitive) and 2 Vampire Clans (Ministry & Caitiff). The game includes a crypt pack with additional cards to customize your decks.

—description from the publisher

This is a standalone expansion for Takaro! that can be played with the original game or on it's own.

Each card features a number of symbols. Each of these symbols will have a direct MÄori translation, which players will need to memorise and learn.

Players will flip over two cards competing to find the matching symbols; the first player to call out the correct translation wins the round.

TÄkaro can be played by ages 4+ with each round lasting 10-15 minutes. It will rely on the recognition of 31 various symbols, and the correct pronunciation of their MÄori names.

—description from the publisher

The Explorers of Terra Fauna is an upcoming deckbuilding, resource management, and engine building game that takes place on a distant sci-fi world far in the future, where various animal and insect creatures have evolved to inherit a world abandoned by the “Ancient Giants”.

Players curate decks around one or more of the main archetypes - Nature, Technology, Beetles and Lizogs. They will use their Action, Day, and Creature cards to explore and travel between the two main market zones - the Wild and Edge. The Wild is a safer place, with less risk and easier engine building opportunities, but fewer ways to generate or gain victory points. The Edge, on the other hand, is a vicious and dangerous place, but every card is powerful and offers either inherent victory points or ways to generate them.

As the game progresses, the players will find that they have ventured perhaps a little too far, and terrifying Superpredators will enter the Edge deck as future Edge cards enter the market row face-down. Stumbling across a Superpredator will cause every player in the Edge to be ambushed by an incredible, devastating attack. Defeating even a single Superpredator will grant a player great renown - and lots of victory points - so players in a strong position will want to seek them out!

In addition to a player's turn having card plays and cleanup, the game progresses over several 'days', three-round periods where players will build their board states and prepare to fight stronger opposition. When night falls, players will discard their Day cards and Creature cards and begin again. The game takes place during a four-day expedition into the unknown, and follows a set escalation along that time frame. At the end of the fourth day, the player with the most points wins!

—description from the designer

Something delicious is cooking up in the kitchen, and as a talented chef, it’s up to you to carefully carve up the right ingredients and turn them into culinary masterpieces. Prepare a wide variety of recipes from around the world, and hype them up to earn extra praise!

In Diced Veggies you take turns with the cleaver, slicing ingredient dice away from the shared chopping block and assigning them to the recipes you’re working on. This unique resource-gathering mechanism is the key to your scrumptious success. The particular veggies that your recipes require isn't your only consideration... you can only take a limited number of pips with each chop, and the right dice values can unlock all sorts of drool-worthy Hypes to boost a recipe's score!

A clever cleaver is all you need to whip up delicious recipes in this dice-slicing game for up to four chefs!

—description from the publisher

Group game with secret roles.
A robbery has just taken place in the town's bank and the thief has managed to escape.
The Sheriff is going to interrogate all the witnesses present to try to draw his portrait.
But it is very likely that the bandit had accomplices, they will certainly lie and give false clues.
The Sheriff will have to rely on the help of the real witnesses to avoid mistakes and will have to be careful with the lies of the accomplices who will know how to defend themselves and accuse the others.

In Witness, you will be either the sheriff, a witness who only tells the truth, or an accomplice who will lie and accuse others.
Witness is a new type of secret role-playing game that will bring you a lot of fun with friends or family.

—description from the publisher

A twist on Rummy.

The aim is to arrange your hand into four melds as follows:

     Three or four cards in suit and sequence (straight flush), Ace counting low only.
     Three or four cards in sequence but all of different suits (blank straight)
     Three or four cards of the same rank
     Three or four cards of different suits totalling 21, counting Ace 1 and face cards 10 each.


At each turn you play as follows:

     Take one card from the spread and add it to your hand
     Make one meld (not more), if you can and wish, by placing three or four cards face up before you
     Make one discard face up from your hand to the spread. Your discard must not be the card you just picked up.


Play continues until one player has laid out four melds. The other(s) may then each make one more draw and meld, if possible.

Scoring
For your initial four-card meld you score the face value of its highest card. For each of the three three-card melds you score the face value of its lowest card. Whoever was first to make their initial four-card meld adds a bonus of 10.

Rocky ‘Roid is an asteroid-mining roll and write in which you individually try to find the best asteroids to mine and then race back to sell the ore you’ve mined in the shared market.

In the first half of the game players choose two of three shared dice to decide where to move and what asteroid they find at that location, optionally using additional fuel to modify the dice for themselves.

Once players have headed home they sell the minerals they have collected one at a time in the order they arrived home, with each sale reducing the price for all other players.

The game comes with multiple maps, each with slightly different rules and more maps will be added over time.

—description from the designer

OLLO is an abstract game that can be played by 2 to 4 players.

Played on a board with 12 marbles glass of each color, the goal is to align 4 marbles of its color.

The rules are very simple, the first player put a marble glass on a corner of the board, then the other players must put their marbles on the board by pushing one or multiple marbles from the outside of the board.

Second and last rule, no marbles can be ejected from the board.

—description from the designer

From the mind of internet funny-guy Jerma985 comes the Grotto Beasts! Trading Card Game!

Players build a deck of cards they will use to battle against an opponent to become a champion. Cards come in four types: Beast, Wish, Grotto and Challenger. Beast cards use their power to attack an opponent's team, while the Grotto cards boost the power or abilities of Beasts. The Wish cards give players extra tricks up their sleeves to pull off special effects. Challengers are used for the special Jerma Rumble variant of the game, letting players team up with the characters of Jerma985's jermaverse.

As players summon cards from their hand, they add cards to their Summoning Pool while their opponent draws cards from their Summoning Pool. The more cards a player draws, the stronger the cards a player may summon.

—description from the designer

It is early in the 20th century. You are a member of mafia. There is a series of horse races coming up and Don has an errand for you. He will be glad if a certain horse ends the season at a certain rank and he will appreciate your help in the matter. Other players are Don's other fixers with similar, non-contradictory errands. You will play as a team trying to accomplish as many orders as possible, because if someone screws up, Don will not care who and will be disappointed in all you. Yet he does not allow you to tell your order to others because the old man is not a believer of sharing information.

Code of Silence is a euro style cooperative game with limited communication. It is played with 3-6 players and also includes a solo variant. Regardless of how many players there are around the table, there are always 6 horses and 6 secret orders in the game. In the beginning everyone knows one secret order but some orders may not be known by anyone.

On your turn you will choose a race card from your hand to play. Every card moves multiple horses and makes progress towards one useful action or another. You will need to make hard decisions where all your moves are ambiguous and what benefits a task often harms another task. The game also includes events that introduces further randomness, a betting system and secondary tasks that give some immediate benefits and victory points.

Code of Silence is a funny yet challenging game with medium complexity where strategy, communication, deduction, intuition play equal parts.

—description from the designer

Gra Roku is a quick and very fun family game where you create your year consisting of up to 12 cards (you play cards representing the 4 seasons: SPRING, SUMMER, AUTUMN, and WINTER.). You try to have cards that give you the most points in your year.

However, you have to be careful because - as you know - nothing happens twice, so each card of the year must have a different symbol! For every card with a symbol you already have in your year, you'll get a negative point! The person who creates the year with the largest number of points wins.

—description from the publisher

Create your own deck with 8 creature or incantation cards and face off against other Lord-Sorcerers to destroy their Stronghold!

This 36-card standalone expansion from Clash of Decks Season 3 adds Counter-Order and Retreat special abilities.

Counter-Order: When the owner is played, move the leftmost creature or incantation card to the rightmost in its owners hand.

Retreat: During the Invocation phase, you can sacrifice the owner in order to gain half its Mana cost, rounded down.

Create your own deck with 8 creature or incantation cards and face off against other Lord-Sorcerers to destroy their Stronghold!

This 36-card standalone expansion from Clash of Decks Season 3 adds Blackmail and Immolation special abilities.

Blackmail: As long as the owner is in game, its owner must play with 1 less card among the 4 leftmost cards in his hand (never less than 1).

Immolation: As long as the owner is in game, each time any player play a card on the same line, they suffer 1 Damage to their Stronghold.

Create your own deck with 8 creature or incantation cards and face off against other Lord-Sorcerers to destroy their Stronghold!

This 36-card standalone expansion from Clash of Decks Season 3 adds Cursed and Backlash special abilities.

Backlash: When the owner is played, deal as much damage to the opponent creature closest to the bridge in the same row as the number of cards on the left side of your Stronghold in your hand.

Cursed: When the owner should return to the rightmost position in its owner's Hand, it returns to the leftmost position instead.

Every player starts with 4 face down cards. When the game starts each player look at one of his card.
On your turn, you start by picking a new card from the discard or draw pile. This card can be played then discarded or used to replace one card from your game.
A card is either a number from 0 to 15 or an action (or both).
The goal is to have less point in front of you than other players. When you think it's the case, say 'Valhalla', each player can then play a last time.
Win 3 times to win the game.

—user summary

Le Clash des Vikings !

Dans ce jeu de défausse mêlant mémoire et stratégie, chaque joueur devra se débarrasser de ses cartes pour atteindre le Valhalla. Mais attention à ne pas provoquer le Ragnarok !
Pour aider les joueurs, les chefs Vikings pourront solliciter l’aide des Figures Divines afin d’attaquer les autres clans.

Qui remportera le Bouclier d’Or et atteindra le Valhalla ?

—description from the publisher

You have delayed cleaning your room for a while... there is junk in all your drawers! Luckily with your eagle eyes you will spot whatever is needed in no time! Flip checklist cards to find out which objects you need to find to complete your task. Take turns with your friends peeking into the drawers of your choice, and call it out when you think you know where each item is. Win pin tokens when everything you need is found in the jumble!

Carrion Eaters is a solo, dice-rolling game of calculated risks for ages 12+ that's played in 5-15 minutes on one poker-sized card using 7 six-sided dice.

You play as carrion eaters attempting to swoop down and pick off re-animated roadkill as they chase after Bobby Butcher. Be careful. If you stay too low to the ground, they may just get you instead!

—description from the designer

Kdovíkdo is a party game based on association, clues and speed.

Each round you draw one of the famous personalities and you try to give your opponents a hint using well-chosen clues.

Your goal is to guess and be guessed. But beware, you only have three chances to guess the best clues. Even you must have fast hands.

Unicorns To The Moon is an action-packed tabletop game for 1-4 players that turns your dreams of being a hotshot venture capitalist (VC) into a reality! Your job as a VC? Invest in ‘Unicorns’ (companies worth a billion or more dollars), and send them to the moon.
In this game you’ll start by defining your strategy. Then, you’ll manage your fund by investing in companies and resources to help those companies become unicorns (worth over $1B). Finally, take your shot at sending unicorns to the moon (worth over $10B), to see who is the best VC! The player with the most money at the end of the game wins!
